sn3.3:4.2: Seated to one side, King Pasenadi said to the Buddha:
sn3.3:4.3: “Sir, for someone who has been born, is there anything apart from old age and death?”
sn3.3:4.4: “Great King, for someone who has been born, there’s nothing apart from old age and death.
sn3.3:4.5: Even for propertied aristocrats, brahmins, or householders—rich, affluent, and wealthy, with lots of gold and silver, lots of property and assets, and lots of money and grain—when they’re born, there’s nothing apart from old age and death.
sn3.3:4.8: Even for mendicants who are perfected—who have ended the defilements, lived the spiritual life, done what had to be done, laid down the burden, achieved their purpose, utterly ended the fetters of rebirth, and are rightly freed through final knowledge—their bodies are liable to break up and be laid to rest.
sn3.3:4.9: This is what the Buddha said. …
sn3.3:5.1: “The fancy chariots of kings wear out,
sn3.3:5.2: and this body too gets old.
sn3.3:5.4: so do the true and good proclaim.”
